CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China Cyclic carbonates are valuable green chemicals with wide-ranging applications, but their conventional synthesis often involves toxic reagents or inefficient catalytic systems. In this work, zirconia catalysts with different crystalline phases (tetragonal, monoclinic, and mixed-phase) were developed and evaluated for the transesterification of 1,2-butanediol with dimethyl carbonate. The tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2) exhibited superior catalytic activity (space-time yield of 41.76 g1,2-BC gcat. −1 h−1) due to favorable surface properties and exposed active (101) facet. This study establishes a green, efficient route for 1,2-butylene carbonate synthesis, providing key insights into catalyst structure-activity relationships. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Transesterification Heterogeneous catalysis Cyclic carbonates Tetragonal Oxygen vacancy Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Cyclic carbonates (CCs) are in high demand globally due to their considerable industrial potential as sustainable and environmentally friendly chemicals and reagents [1]. They serve a wide range of applications such as polar aprotic solvents, in Li-ion batteries, pharmaceutical products, and essential polymers, such as polycarbonates and polyurethanes, attributed to their elevated boiling point and solvency [2]. Among CCs, the 5-membered cyclic carbonates such as ethylene carbonate (EC), propylene carbonate (PC), butylene carbonate (BC), and glycerol carbonate (GC) are predominantly utilized due to their low toxicity and low volatility [3]. 1,2-butylene carbonate (1,2-BC) is a significant 5-membered cyclic carbonate, extensively employed in the synthesis of plasticizers, surfactants, and polymers, as well as serving as a high-polarity solvent in lithium-ion batteries [4]. It is also used as a degreasing solvent, paint stripper, wood adhesive resin, and lubricant [5]. Traditional methods for CCs production, such as the phosgene route and reactions involving CO2 or urea, often rely on toxic or corrosive reagents like phosgene, pyridine, or chlorinated compounds. These approaches suffer from drawbacks including low selectivity, undesirable by-products, and high costs [6–8]. So, the development of a non-toxic and environmentally benign route is highly required. Recently, the synthesis of CCs by transesterification of diols and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) has attracted significant attention, owing to the mild reaction conditions and the use of non-toxic, environmentally benign raw materials [9,10]. The synthesis of 1,2-BC by transesterification reaction involves 1,2-butanediol (1,2-BDO) and DMC. DMC is a non-toxic, eco-friendly compound that has been certified by the European Union and is widely regarded as a safer alternative to chlorine-based reagents for transesterification reactions [11]. Another crucial raw material, 1,2-BDO, could be largely derived primarily as a by-product from the well-known coal-to-ethylene glycol process [12], resulting in a low-cost material for the transesterification reaction. Notably, 1,2-BC is a key intermediate in a green synthetic route to 1,2-butylene oxide (BO), an important precursor for value-added polyurethanes. BO has unique properties to enhance the durability of MDI-based polyurethane [13]. Prior research on the synthesis of cyclic carbonates by transesterification of diol and dialkyl carbonate was mainly focused on the investigation of catalysts [14,15]. Several homogenous and heterogeneous catalytic systems have been studied in the past. However, homogenous catalysts have drawbacks such as poor selectivity, long reaction time, and difficulty in separation [16,17]. Meanwhile, heterogeneous catalysts, such as K2CO3, γ-Al2O3, CaO, hydrotalcite, and mixed metal oxides, exhibit limitations such as solubility in the reaction mixture, reduced stability, low selectivity, and deactivation [18–20]. Therefore, a catalytic system with moderate reaction conditions and stable catalytic activity is highly desired for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates. It is well known that the basicity of the catalyst plays a vital role in the transesterification process. While few studies also reported the importance of acidity in this reaction [9]. Therefore, it was important to elucidate the relationship between the activity and acid-base property of the catalyst, and finally develop a highly efficient and stable catalyst for the transesterification reaction. In recent years, zirconium oxide (ZrO2) catalyst has drawn significant interest because of its unique surface chemical characteristics, specifically its redox and acid-base properties [21–23]. ZrO2 exists in three different polymorphs: tetragonal (t-ZrO2), monoclinic (m-ZrO2), and cubic (c-ZrO2), each exhibiting distinct acid-base characteristics [24]. It is reported that crystalline phase composition also influences the acid-basic properties of ZrO2 [25]. Researchers have reported different catalytic performances of the crystal phases in their work [26,27]. The crystal phase impact of ZrO2 has been extensively studied in several catalytic processes such as ethanol coupling to n-butanol, H2/CO2 interaction, dehydration of glycerol, steam reforming, and synthesis of DMC [25,28,29]. It was reported that t-ZrO2 exhibits stronger basicity than the monoclinic phase [30], which makes it more desirable for the transesterification reaction. In addition, numerous studies have also emphasized the critical role of surface hydroxyl groups on the ZrO2 surface, serving as amphoteric Zr-OH sites [28]. In general, transesterification requires efficient activation of the OH bond. However, traditional solid catalysts often suffer from insufficient or imbalanced acid-base site densities, leading to low conversion rates and poor reactant interaction. This work addresses key challenges in the diol transesterification reaction, including low catalyst activity, poor stability, unclear catalytic mechanisms, and catalyst deactivation, by developing efficient catalytic system for the synthesis of 1,2-BC via transesterification. In this work, three ZrO2 catalysts with different crystalline phases were prepared using the hydrothermal method at different temperatures and subsequently characterized by XRD, BET, SEM, TEM, HRTEM, and XPS. Their catalytic activity was evaluated for the transesterification of 1,2-BDO with DMC to synthesize 1,2-BC. The influence of the crystal phase and acid-base properties on the catalytic performance of ZrO2 catalysts was also investigated. To further explore the reaction pathway and the adsorption behavior of reactants on the catalyst surface, in situ DRIFTS, in situ IR, and DFT calculations were performed. The effects of reaction temperature, reactant molar ratio, catalyst dosage, and reaction time on the synthesis of 1,2-BC were systematically studied. Additionally, the general applicability of ZrO2 catalysts for the transesterification of various diols was examined. The long-term stability of the catalyst was evaluated using a fixed-bed reactor. This work aims to establish an acid-base catalytic system to facilitate the efficient synthesis of 1,2-BC. It provides a sustainable and environmentally friendly strategy for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates (Scheme 1 ). Experimental section Materials Zr(NO3)4·5H2O and Zr(SO4)2·4H2O were purchased from Shandong Xiya Chemical Co., Ltd. NaOH, and CH3COONa were purchased from Xilong Chemical Co., Ltd. DMC and 1,2-BDO were purchased from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All reagents were analytical grade and were used without further purification. Catalyst preparation ZrO2, designated as Zr-100, Zr-180, and Zr-200, was synthesized by the hydrothermal method. In a typical synthesis of Zr-100, 0.004 mol of Zr(NO3)4·5H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of water, and 0.48 mol of NaOH was dissolved in 70 mL of water. The NaOH solution was added dropwise, yielding a white precipitate Zr(OH)4. The slurry was then transferred to a 200 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and hydrothermally treated at 100 °C for 6 h. The resultant white solid was filtered, rinsed with deionized water and ethanol to a neutral pH, and dried for 6 h at 80 °C. Finally, the samples were calcined at 500 °C in a muffle furnace for 3 h. The preparation procedure for Zr-180 is similar to Zr-100, as explained above, the only difference being that the hydrothermal treatment temperature was maintained at 180 °C for 24 h. The preparation of Zr-200 followed a previously reported method but was modified [31]. In a typical synthesis for Zr-200, 0.355 g of Zr(SO4)2·4H2O and 0.060 g of CH3COONa were dissolved into 12 mL of deionized water. The solution was kept under stirring until it became colorless. The slurry was then transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and hydrothermally treated at 200 °C for 6 h. The precipitate was collected by centrifugation, washed several times with deionized water, and dried at 60 °C for 6 h. The catalyst calcination period was not specified; hence, the sample was calcined at 645 °C for 3 h. The numbers in the catalyst name refer to the hydrothermal treatment temperature. Catalyst characterization The crystal structure of the catalyst was characterized by wide-angle X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a PANalytical Empyrean diffractometer. Test conditions: Cu Kα radiation was used, with a scanning range of 2θ = 5°−90°, a scanning speed of 10°/min, a working voltage of 40 kV, and a working current of 40 mA. The textural properties of the catalyst were investigated using N₂ adsorption-desorption measurements recorded on a Micromeritics Tristar II 3020 instrument. Before testing, to remove possible physically adsorbed impurities (e.g., H2O, CO2), the catalyst sample was heated to 200 °C and degassed under vacuum for 4 h. After degassing, the adsorption and desorption experiments were conducted at −196 °C. The BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) method was used to calculate the specific surface area, while the BJH (Barrett-Joyner-Halenda) method was used to determine the pore size distribution based on the desorption branch of the N2 adsorption isotherm. When the relative pressure (P/P₀) = 0.99, the total pore volume was calculated based on the amount of adsorbed N2. The morphology of the catalyst was examined using Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) with a Zeiss Gemini 300 instrument. Before analysis, the catalyst samples were evacuated and sputter-coated with gold to enhance electrical conductivity. Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) was performed using a JEOL JEM-F200 (Japan) instrument. Samples were prepared by ultrasonically dispersing the ground catalyst powder in ethanol for 10 min. A small amount of the dispersed liquid was then dropped onto a copper microgrid and dried before testing. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument (USA) to analyze the valence states of elements on the catalyst surface. The XPS spectrum was calibrated based on the binding energy of C 1s (284.8 eV). Spectral peaks were fitted using Avantage software. NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD experiments were conducted using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 (USA) to investigate the acid-base strength and number of active sites on the catalyst. For each experiment, 0.1 g of fresh catalyst was pre-treated with helium gas (50 mL/min) at 200 °C for 1 h to remove surface impurities. After cooling naturally to 50 °C, a 10 % NH3/He (or CO2/He) mixture was introduced at 50 mL/min for 1 h until surface adsorption reached saturation. The catalyst was then purged with He gas for 1 h to remove weakly adsorbed species. Desorption of NH3 or CO2 was performed at a heating rate of 10 °C/min, ramping up to 800 °C under flowing He gas. TPD profiles were recorded over the 25–800 °C range. The Raman spectra of ZrO2 was recorded using a DXR3 Raman Microscope with a 514 nm laser wavelength. Operando IR spectroscopy was performed using a Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer equipped with an MCT detector and an AgX probe. The catalytic reaction was monitored in an autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a heating jacket. The reaction temperature was fixed at 120 °C to match the catalytic conditions. In situ DRIFTS spectroscopy was carried out using a Thermo Scientific Nicolet 6700 infrared spectrometer, equipped with an MCT detector and a BaF2 window, to investigate reactant adsorption on the catalyst surface. Before the experiment, ZrO2 was pretreated at 200 °C for 1 h. 1,2-BDO vapor was introduced into the sample cell at room temperature until adsorption reached saturation. After removing physically adsorbed 1,2-BDO with N2, the temperature was gradually increased to 120 °C at 10 °C/min. Spectra were recorded at 25, 50, 70, 100, and 120 °C. A similar in situ DRIFTS procedure was used for DMC adsorption experiments. The catalyst’s stability was tested using a fixed-bed reactor. After pelletizing the catalyst using a tablet press, 1 g of catalyst (40–60 mesh particle size) was loaded into the reactor bed. Continuous operation was conducted under optimal reaction conditions for 100 h. Catalyst performance The transesterification reaction between 1,2-BDO and DMC was conducted in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave under self-generated pressure. In the reaction, 1.9 g of 1,2-BDO, 7.6 g of DMC, and 5 wt. % of catalyst (with respect to 1,2-BDO) were placed in the autoclave. No gas was used to replace the air in the reactor. The reactor was then placed in a heating jacket with continuous magnetic stirring at 120 °C for 40 min. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled, and the reaction mixture was removed. The product was separated using a high-speed centrifuge, and ethanol and biphenyl were added as the solvent and standard substance, respectively. No insoluble compounds were found in the reaction mixture. The product was quantitatively analyzed by Shimadzu GC-2020 and qualitatively analyzed by Gas Chromatography Mass Spectrometry (GC–MS). (The results of the gas chromatography analysis of the by-products are shown in (Supporting Information Fig. S1). DFT calculations Theoretical calculations were performed using density functional theory (DFT). The spin polarization calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP), employing plane-wave basis sets along the projector augmented-wave method. The DFT calculations are detailed in the Supporting Information. Results and discussion Catalyst characterization The textural properties of the catalysts were analyzed through N2 adsorption-desorption measurements. The resulting adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions are shown in Fig. 1 . All three samples displayed Type IV isotherms with distinct H2-type hysteresis loops [32,33], indicative of mesoporous materials. This is further supported by the pore size distribution curves in Fig. 1b, which reveal prominent peaks within the mesopore range of 2–50 nm. The specific surface area (SBET), pore size (Dp), and pore volume (Vp) of the ZrO2 catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . Among them, Zr-100 exhibited the highest specific surface area of 122.39 m2/g, suggesting a greater exposure of active sites and potentially enhanced catalytic performance [34]. The crystalline structures of the ZrO₂ catalysts were investigated using X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), as shown in Fig. 2 a. The XRD results confirm the successful synthesis of the ZrO₂ catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2a, the diffraction peaks of the Zr-180 and Zr-200 catalysts at 24.0°, 28.1°, 31.4°, 34.1°, 40.6°, and 49.2° were assigned to the (011), (−111), (111), (002), (−211), and (220) planes, respectively, corresponding to the monoclinic phase (JCPDS No. 83-0942 and JCPDS No. 81-1314) [35]. In contrast, the diffraction peaks of Zr-100 at 30.2°, 35.2°, 50.4°, and 59.9° were assigned to the (101), (002), (112), and (103) planes, corresponding to the tetragonal phase (JCPDS No. 80-0784) [36]. No additional peaks related to impurities or precursor residues were observed in the XRD patterns. Notably, Zr-200 exhibited weaker diffraction peaks compared to Zr-180, which could be attributed to the shorter hydrothermal treatment time. Raman spectroscopy is sensitive to the polarizability of oxygen ions and functions as a fingerprint to differentiate between polymorphs; it could detect variations in the energy levels of particular molecular vibrations and is more responsive to temperature-induced changes in ZrO2 crystallinity compared to XRD [37]. Therefore, to further validate the phases, the ZrO2 catalysts were characterized by Raman spectroscopy, and the result is shown in Fig. 2b It is reported that t-ZrO2 shows 6 Raman-active vibrational modes: two B1g, one A1g, and three Eg modes that are stable up to 1900 °C [37]. In contrast, m-ZrO2 shows 18 Raman-active vibrational modes (9Ag and 9 Bg) stable up to 1200 °C. Fig. 2b illustrates that Zr-100 exhibited 4 Raman-active vibrational modes corresponding to the tetragonal phase at 148 cm−1, 272 cm−1, 320 cm−1, and 606 cm−1, which is in agreement with the reported literature [38,39]. The observed band broadening mainly arises from disorder in the oxygen sub-lattice. As reported by Cai et al. [40], structural disorder enables Raman scattering from additional points in the Brillouin zone. This first-order scattering mechanism leads to spectral broadening [38]. While, Zr-180 showed a pure monoclinic phase with 9 Raman-active vibrational modes with peaks centering at 184 cm−1 (Ag+Bg), 220 cm−1 (Bg), 306 cm−1 (Ag), 340 cm−1 (Ag), 381 cm−1 (Bg), 478 cm−1 (Ag), 537 cm−1 (Bg), 559 cm−1 (Ag), and 617 cm−1 (Ag), which are the characteristic peaks for the m-ZrO2 [41,42]. The Raman modes associated with the monoclinic phase are labelled ‘M,’ while those of the tetragonal phase are marked ‘T’. Raman spectra of Zr-200 confirmed the presence of both tetragonal and monoclinic phases, as evidenced by the appearance of tetragonal Eg peaks at 267 cm−1 and 453 cm−1 [37,43]. Tetragonal phase content (percent tetragonality %T) was estimated using an equation by Godlewski [41] (Eq. (3)) and the phase (%) of Zr-100, Zr-180, and Zr-200 is shown in Table 2 . The analysis shows that Zr-200 consists of approximately 39 % tetragonal and 61 % monoclinic phases. For comparison, Zr-100 exhibits a fully tetragonal structure, while Zr-180 shows a pure monoclinic phase. These findings confirm that Zr-200 predominantly adopts a monoclinic structure, but retains a significant fraction of the tetragonal phase due to its synthesis conditions. As discussed by Marcos et al. [43,44] the synthesis of the monoclinic phase is favored at elevated temperatures and prolonged heating time, whereas, the tetragonal phase is favored at lower temperatures because the monoclinic phase requires higher surface free energy than the tetragonal phase. As reported by Machmudah et al. [45] the synthesis of high-crystalline zirconia is achieved at 180 °C and a 12 h reaction time. This explains the highly crystalline structure of Zr-180 and the formation of the tetragonal phase of Zr-100 at 100 °C. The formation of a mixed-phase zirconia in case of Zr-200 can be attributed to its synthesis condition. Zr-100, Zr-180, and Zr-200 are designated as t-ZrO2, m-ZrO2, and mp-ZrO2, respectively, where “t”, “m”, and “mp” correspond to tetragonal, monoclinic, and mixed-phase. (3) % T ( Zr O 2 ) = I T 1 I M 1 + I T 1 + I M 2 Where I stand for the particular intensity of monoclinic (IM1 = 184 cm−1 and IM2 = 220 cm−1) and tetragonal phase (IT1 = 267 cm−1). The microscopic morphology and particle size of the ZrO2 catalysts were investigated by TEM and SEM as shown in Fig. 3 . The SEM (Fig. 3a,d,g) images show that the three ZrO2 catalysts, exhibit spherical, cylindrical, and flower morphologies, respectively. Zr-100 shows agglomeration, with an average particle size of 31.3 nm, which is relatively smaller than that of the other catalysts. The average length of Zr-180 is 494.1 nm. The average particle size of Zr-200 is 384.8. The HRTEM image of Zr-100 (Fig. 3c) shows an interplanar distance of 0.29 nm belonging to (101) crystal plane [46,47]. The 0.31 nm lattice stripe of Zr-180 and Zr-200 belong to (−111) crystal plane (Fig. 3f,i) [48]. These results were consistent with XRD and Raman, further confirming the crystalline phase of the ZrO2 catalysts. The electronic state of Zr and O elements on the surface of ZrO2 samples were analyzed using XPS. The Zr 3d spectrum deconvoluted into two peaks at around 182 eV and 184 eV, which are attributed to 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 respectively [49], as shown in Fig. 4 a. Zr in ZrO2 is present in two states, Zr4+which appear at high binding energy, and Zr (4- x )+which appears at low binding energy and is often associated with oxygen vacancies [42]. The binding energy of Zr4+ species in pure ZrO2 is stated to be approximately 182.6 eV [50]. Nevertheless, all three samples showed somewhat lower binding energy, possibly as a result of oxygen vacancies. Sulaiman et al. [42] reported that the Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 peaks, for t-ZrO2 and m-ZrO2 samples were seen at 182.7 eV and 184.7 eV, and 182.2 eV and 184.6 eV, respectively. As can be seen in Fig. 4a, the 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 peaks for Zr-100 (t-ZrO2), appeared to be at lower B.E, around 182.3 eV and 184.7 eV. For Zr-180 (m-ZrO2) and Zr-200 (mp-ZrO2), the peaks ascribed to 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 also appeared at lower binding energy compared to the values discussed above for m-ZrO2. The binding energy shift towards a lower value is often associated with oxygen vacancies in the ZrO2 lattice [51]. In addition, both peaks of the three catalysts are separated by 2.4 eV, which is in accordance with the reported literature [52]. Fig. 4b displays the O 1s XPS spectra of the catalysts, which revealed three oxygen species on the ZrO2 surface. The peak at 528−530 eV corresponds to surface lattice oxygen (denoted as Oβ). The peak in the energy range of 530–533 eV corresponds to the surface-adsorbed oxygen (denoted as Oα), while surface hydroxyl groups appear above 533 eV [53,54]. The quantitative results for O α ( O α + O β ) are calculated according to Eq. (4), and are shown in Table 1. The order of Oα is Zr-100 (28.3 %) > Zr-180 (25.4 %) > Zr-200 (25.1 %). The presence of abundant surface-adsorbed oxygen species enhances the adsorption and activation of reactants, thus accelerating the transesterification reaction. These XPS features suggested that Zr is present in the reduced Zr(4- x )+ state, with some oxygen vacancy in the case of all the phases. However, it should be noted that the proportion of Zr4+ species in all samples is higher than that of Zr(4- x )+. Oα concentration was calculated according to the Eq. (4), where A O α and A O β represent the peak areas corresponding to Oα (surface-adsorbed oxygen) and Oβ (lattice oxygen), respectively. (4) C [ O α ] % = A O α A O α + A O β × 100 % The acid-base characteristics of ZrO2 are essential for its catalytic activity, and these sites also have a critical function in the transesterification reaction of 1,2-BDO and DMC. The acid-base characteristics of ZrO2 were investigated using CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD. The results revealed several broad desorption bands across the 50–800 °C temperature range. It has been commonly observed that the position and area of the desorption peak are strongly connected to the strength and number of acid-base pairs [55]. Fig. 4c shows the CO2-TPD desorption peaks of ZrO2 catalysts. CO2-TPD region is distributed into weak (less than or around 200 °C), moderate-strength (200–400 °C), and strong basic sites (more than 400 °C) [54]. In Fig. 4c, it can be seen that CO2-TPD profiles for Zr-100 showed CO2 desorption peaks at 209 °C, 426 °C, and 661 °C indicating the presence of weak and strong basic sites. Zr-180 showed peaks around 145 °C, 364 °C, 554 °C, and 712 °C indicating the presence of weak, medium, and strong basic sites. However, Zr-200 showed desorption peaks at around 357 °C and 627 °C. Zr-100 exhibits the highest basicity compared to Zr-180 and Zr-200 indicating that t-ZrO2 is richer in basic sites compared to m-ZrO2 and mp-ZrO2 [56]. Fig. 4d shows the NH3-TPD profile of the three ZrO2 catalysts. The desorption in the low-temperature zone (less than or around 200 °C) corresponds to weak acid sites, and the desorption peaks in the 200∼400 °C and the 400∼800 °C region correspond to medium and strong acid sites, respectively [54]. Zr-180 exhibits only strong (513 and 677 °C) acid desorption peaks. Zr-100 displayed NH3 desorption peaks around weak (154 °C) and strong (439 and 662 °C) acid regions. Zr-200 shows peaks around medium, and strong acid regions. The quantitative acid and base densities are summarized in Table S1. Catalyst evaluation The performance of ZrO2 catalysts with different phases in the transesterification reaction of 1,2-BDO to synthesize 1,2-BC was evaluated, and the results are shown in Fig. 5 a. A mere 3.5 % of the 1,2-BC was produced when no catalyst was used. The introduction of ZrO2 revealed a significant influence on the catalyst's performance, with Zr-100 demonstrating the highest catalytic activity observed. Compared to Zr-200 (3.8 %) and Zr-180 (30.2 %), Zr-100 had a superior 1,2-BC yield of 98.4 %. The order of catalytic activity was Zr-100 > Zr-180 > Zr-200. Understanding the structure-activity relationship of the catalyst is essential. The Zr-100 catalyst preferentially exposed the active (101) facet, which is beneficial to the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules. In addition, infrared spectroscopy study of zirconia has revealed that the surface of zirconia is rich in OH groups which act as amphoteric species—capable of functioning as either Brønsted acid or Brønsted basic sites depending on the reaction environment and the nature of the reactants [28,30,57]. These OH groups and the Lewis acid–base sites (Zr(4-x)/O2–) on ZrO2 surfaces are significant for the catalytic activity of ZrO2 [56]. Apart from the phase composition, the acid-base characteristics of ZrO2 also significantly influence the reaction activity. As revealed by the TPD results, the Zr-100 catalyst exhibited more robust acid-base sites than the other two catalysts, which is deemed as one of the optimal parameters for the transesterification reaction. A representation of the relationship between acid-basic sites and catalytic activity can be seen in Fig. 5b The presence of more basic sites along with suitable acidic sites contributes to a more efficient formation of 1,2-BC [58]. Some reports indicate that the distribution of acid and basic sites is influenced by the crystal phases of ZrO2 [25]. Therefore, it can be inferred that Zr-100, which mainly exposes the (101) surface, exhibits high catalytic activity for 1,2-BDO transesterification due to its high specific surface area, abundant oxygen vacancies, and high acid−base sites. Reaction mechanism The reaction mechanism for cyclic carbonate synthesis has been examined in several studies, although the pathway remains ambiguous. To examine the potential reaction pathways of 1,2-BDO transesterification, the supernatant of the solution was analyzed using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS), with the findings shown in Fig. S1. The peak at tR=4.4 min belongs to the 1,2-BC (product) and the other tiny peaks imply reactants which include 1,2-BDO and DMC. The peak at tR=1.4 min corresponds to the ethanol which is a solvent peak. No other peak for intermediate was found. To get a better understanding of the reaction pathway an automated reactor equipped with an operando IR spectroscopic probe is utilized to monitor the reaction process in real-time, allowing for the efficient identification of raw material consumption, intermediate changes, and production trends in the reaction system [59]. The three-dimensional conversion of 1,2-BDO and DMC into 1,2-BC under infrared monitoring using a catalyst is depicted in Fig. 6 a. The real-time trends of the in situ IR signals of the characteristic peaks of 1,2-BC and DMC are shown in Fig. 6b. According to the reported literature, the peaks at 1753 cm−1 and 1453 cm−1 refer to the stretching vibrations of the carbonyl (C=O) group and bending vibrations of the C-H bond of DMC, respectively, both are regarded as the characteristic peaks of DMC [60]. The typical peak v(C=O) at 1743 cm−1, indicative of polycarbonate stretching vibrations, was not detected by operando IR spectroscopy, suggesting that no significant polycarbonate byproducts were generated [61]. The peaks at 1814 cm−1 and 1148 cm−1 are due to the stretching vibrations of (C=O) and (C-O) of 1,2-BC respectively. These peaks are also considered the unique (C=O) stretching vibration and skeletal stretch absorption peak of cyclic carbonates [55,62]. The peaks at 1059 cm−1 correspond to the stretching vibrations of v(CO) of 1,2-BDO [55]. It can be seen that after some time, the intensity of vibrational peaks of reactants decreases and the intensity of vibrational peaks for the product increases and finally achieves equilibrium. Furthermore, the operando IR spectroscopy monitoring did not reveal any significant intermediate product formation. Previous investigations also suggest that the interaction between diol and DMC involves a transient intermediate that is difficult to detect [63]. As previously stated, the intermediate generated in the transesterification synthesis of 1,2-BC is likewise short-lived and not observable as other cyclic carbonates [64]. As reported by Wang et al. [14] the intermediate for a similar reaction system is termed 2,3-dihydroxy propyl methyl carbonate. Bristow et al. [65] also reported intermediate hydroxy ethyl methyl carbonate (HEMC) in a similar reaction system. So, the possible reaction intermediate for 1,2-BDO and DMC can be hydroxy butyl methyl carbonate (HBMC). Since the structures of HBMC and DMC are similar, it was assumed that excessive DMC suppressed the spectral structure of HBMC. The interaction between reactants and catalysts was examined using the in situ DRIFTS performed at various temperatures. In situ DRIFTS experiments for the adsorption of 1,2-BDO on ZrO2 were carried out and the results are shown in Fig. 6c–e. The negative band around 3707 cm−1 is ascribed to the OH stretching vibrations of terminal (monodentate) hydroxyl groups [55,66]. According to Plyler's study, the band around 3696 cm−1 represents the hydroxyl of adsorbed 1,2-BDO [67]. The band around 1298 cm−1 is referred to as the CH bending vibrations of CH2. The bands around 1097 cm−1 and 1059 cm−1 belong to the v(CO) stretching vibrations of on-top and bridged butoxides [55,66,68]. Fig. S4 illustrates that Zr-100 exhibited a peak for bridged butoxide adsorption (1059 cm−1), alongside on-top butoxide, in contrast to Zr-180 and Zr-200. In the v(OH) region, it can be noted that a broad feature between 3000 and 3500 cm−1 appears, attributed to the hydrogen-bonded OH groups [66]. There is a possibility that certain OH groups on the ZrO2 surface react with the H of the 1,2-BDO, leading to the formation of water-type species, which contribute to the broad feature observed above 3000 cm−1 [68]. Additionally, the negative growth of the OH band indicated a decrease in surface hydroxyls which was accompanied by the simultaneous increase of the CH and CO peaks, 1298, 1097, and 1059 cm−1, indicating 1,2-BDO adsorption [55]. As can be seen, the wide OH stretch appeared only on Zr-100 implying strong adsorption of 1,2-BDO on t-ZrO2. Generally, the hydroxyl groups on the ZrO2 surface interact with the reactants, and hence play an important role in the adsorption of 1,2-BDO [68]. In situ DRIFTS results of DMC adsorption on the ZrO2 catalyst are summarized in Fig. 6f–h. It has been reported that DMC disassociates on the catalyst surface into methoxy and methoxycarbonyl [60]. Both methoxy and methoxycarbonyl groups were discovered on the ZrO2 surface, as confirmed by the emergence of their unique infrared bands. The IR features of adsorbed methoxycarbonyl are around 1294 cm−1 [vas (OC-O)] and 1451 cm−1 [δs(C–H)], whereas of methoxy are evident around 2961 cm−1 vas (CH) and 2806 cm−1 vs(CH). The bands around 1041 cm−1 and 1106 cm−1 v(CO) are attributed to bridging methoxy and on-top methoxy respectively [60,68]. CO stretching vibrations assigned to the methoxy group are absent in the case of Zr-180 and Zr-200 as compared with Zr-100, implying the incomplete disassociation of DMC. The IR bands around 1780 cm−1 and 1765 cm−1 in the v(C=O) region are associated with the physisorbed DMC [68]. As the temperature increased, these bands disappeared indicating DMC desorption [69]. For Zr-200, the carbonyl band remained unchanged even at 100 °C, indicating incomplete desorption of DMC [60]. For Zr-100 and Zr-180, the carbonyl and methoxycarbonyl bands begin to diminish at 50 °C, indicating significant desorption of DMC. Hence, it can be concluded that 1,2-BDO and DMC were adsorbed onto Zr-100 with appropriate adsorption strength, exhibiting strong interactions with the catalyst surface. The abundant acid−base sites and oxygen defects on t-ZrO2–100 are favorable for the adsorption and activation of the reactants. As mentioned earlier, Zr-100 exhibited a tetragonal phase and Zr-180 showed a monoclinic phase with varying oxygen vacancy concentrations and acid-base characteristics. Therefore, (101) and (−111) surface models were built to simulate t-ZrO2–100 and m-ZrO2–180, respectively. The ZrO2 surface models and reactant adsorption models are shown in Fig. S5. Since, the ZrO2 (101) surface has higher oxygen vacancies compared to the (−111) surface, therefore, to further confirm the influence of oxygen vacancies on reactant adsorption, the adsorption energies of 1,2-BDO and DMC on t-ZrO2 (101) and m-ZrO2 (−111) surfaces were determined using DFT, as shown in Fig. 7 . The adsorption energies of 1,2-BDO and DMC on m-ZrO2 (−111) were 1.85 eV and 1.21 eV respectively, whereas the adsorption energies on t-ZrO2 (101) were higher, 2.54 eV and 1.86 eV, respectively. It has been reported that the introduction of oxygen vacancies on the surface of t-ZrO2 catalysts enhances phase stability and the adsorption of reactants on the catalyst’s surface [70]. Therefore, the adsorption of 1,2-BDO and DMC on the t-ZrO2 (101) surface was relatively stronger. t-ZrO2–100 with rich oxygen defects and acid-base sites facilitates the adsorption and activation of the reactant molecules and showed excellent catalytic performance for the 1,2-BDO transesterification reaction. Based on the above studies, the proposed reaction mechanism of transesterification of 1,2-BDO with DMC to synthesize 1,2-BC is shown in Scheme 2 . The unsaturated Zr sites adjacent to oxygen vacancies on the ZrO2 surface were considered acid sites, and the O adjacent to the unsaturated Zr on the surface serves as basic sites. Firstly, the 1,2-BDO and DMC are adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst. The surface hydroxyl groups of ZrO2 interact with 1,2-BDO, resulting in the formation of a strong nucleophile. The nucleophilic 1,2-BDO attacks the carbonyl group of DMC, forming the intermediate on the surface of the catalyst, accompanied by the elimination of one methanol molecule. The intermediate then undergoes rearrangement on the surface of the ZrO2 catalyst with the removal of another methanol molecule, and 1,2-BC is formed as a product. Investigation of reaction parameters For the transesterification of 1,2-BDO, Zr-100 with high catalytic activity was used to evaluate the effect of different reaction parameters. The effect of reaction temperature on the transesterification of 1,2-BDO with DMC was investigated in the range of 100 to 140 °C, as illustrated in Fig. 8 a. The catalyst exhibited consistently high selectivity (99 %) across all tested temperatures. As the temperature increased from 100 to 110 °C, the conversion of 1,2-BDO rose sharply from 23.8 % to 68.4 %. This enhancement can be attributed to the increased frequency of collisions between reactant molecules and active sites, which helps to overcome the activation energy barrier and accelerate the catalytic reaction [71]. The conversion further increased to a maximum of 99.3 % at 120 °C. However, a slight decrease in conversion was observed when the temperature was raised to 140 °C, dropping to 97.8 %. This decline may result from the accelerated desorption of 1,2-BDO and DMC from the catalyst surface at elevated temperatures, leading to a reduced surface concentration of reactants and, consequently, fewer molecules available for the reaction. Despite this minor decrease, the change in conversion is not significant, and the catalyst remains highly stable even at elevated temperatures. Therefore, 120 °C was selected as the optimal reaction temperature for the Zr-100 catalyst. The effect of the raw materials (DMC/BDO) molar ratios on the synthesis of 1,2-BC is shown in Fig. 8b The selectivity of 1,2-BC was stable at around 99 %, implying that the different molar ratios did not affect the selectivity of 1,2-BC. When the molar ratio increased from 1:1 to 3:1, the conversion of 1,2-BDO gradually rose from 81.2 % to 87.6 %. Further increasing the molar ratio to 4:1 enhanced the conversion to nearly 99.2 %. Excess DMC is added to promote the reversible reaction, enhancing conversion and yield. This approach increases surface contact between reactants and catalyst active sites improving molecular interactions and reaction kinetics [16]. However, with the continued increase in DMC/BDO molar ratio to 5:1, the conversion of 1,2-BDO drops to 74.3 %. The excess of DMC serves as a diluent, and restricts diol catalyst contact, resulting in lowered conversion [72]. Therefore, 4:1 was selected as the optimal molar ratio. The influence of catalyst dose on 1,2-BC production was also examined (Fig. 8c). The increasing amount of catalyst dose from 0.5 % to 5 % resulted in an increase in conversion from 51 % to 99 %, while selectivity remained consistent at around 99 %. The conversion dropped off quickly when the catalyst dosage was increased to 7 %. High catalyst concentration may reduce the desorption rate of product from the catalyst’s surface, as a result lowering the conversion [73,74]. As a result, 5 % was chosen as an ideal catalyst dose. When it comes to reaction parameters, reaction time is among the most crucial ones. Therefore, the effect of reaction time was also investigated. The impact of reaction time, ranging from 10 to 50 min, on the synthesis of 1,2-BC was examined, and the results are shown in Fig. 8d The conversion of 1,2-BDO varied significantly with reaction time. When the reaction time extends from 10 to 40 min, the conversion of 1,2-BDO rapidly escalates from 64 % to 99 %. The conversion rate of 1,2-BDO almost remained constant when the reaction time was prolonged to 50 min. The selectivity of 1,2-BC remained at about 99 % throughout all the reaction times. Consequently, a reaction period of 40 min is optimal for the synthesis of 1,2-BC. Under the above-mentioned optimized reaction parameters, the yield of 1,2-BC was almost 98.4 % and 1,2-BDO was nearly fully converted. Since this reaction pathway has been rarely reported, catalysts involved in the same or similar transesterification processes are compared in Table S2. By evaluating factors such as product selectivity, catalytic stability, recyclability, and space-time yield, Zr-100 was found to exhibit a higher space-time yield (41.76 g1,2-BC g−1 cat. h−1) along with excellent long-term stability, underscoring its strong potential as a promising heterogeneous catalyst. Long-term stability of Zr-100 catalyst Investigation of the catalyst’s long-term performance and stability is considered an important aspect of industrial application. Therefore, long-term experiments were conducted in a fixed bed over a Zr-100 catalyst under optimized reaction conditions of 120 °C reaction temperature, 4:1 molar ratio of DMC/BDO, and weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) 18 h−1. The results showed that the catalyst was stable enough to achieve >95.0 % yield and >99.0 % selectivity over approximately 100 h (Fig. 8e), indicating satisfied stability of Zr-100 for the transesterification reaction of 1,2-BDO and DMC. To examine the structural and morphological changes in the catalyst after a 100 h long-term experiment, XRD, XPS, SEM, and TPD analyses were conducted on the recovered catalyst. An ICP-OES analysis was performed on the post-reaction solution to determine any potential loss of Zr during the process. The results showed that the Zr content in the reaction solution was 0.034 ppm, indicating minimal and insignificant leaching. The XRD patterns of fresh and used Zr-100 (Fig. S6) revealed that both the position and intensity of the diffraction peaks remained largely unchanged, confirming the stability of the tetragonal crystalline phase after the experiment. SEM images of the catalyst before and after the reaction (Fig. S7) showed that the catalyst’s surface became rougher and lost its tiny spherical morphology, likely due to prolonged reaction time. XPS analysis was conducted to examine the surface chemistry of the catalyst after use (Fig. S8). A shift in the binding energy of the Zr 3d peaks was observed in the XPS spectrum, indicating an alteration in the electronic environment of Zr 3d, as evidenced by the shift in Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 [75]. Despite this change, the peak separation remained constant at 2.4 eV. Additionally, the concentration of Oα in the O 1 s spectra was determined, showing a decrease from 28.3 % to 20.2 %. To further assess changes in the acid and basic sites of the recycled Zr-100 catalyst, NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD measurements were performed (Fig. S9). The total acidity of the catalyst decreased from 1.29 to 0.95 mmol g −1 after use, whereas the total basicity increased from 0.70 to 0.83 mmol g −1. The quantitative results are summarized in Table S4. Fig. S9a illustrates that the weak basic sites of Zr-100 decreased after recycling, while the medium-strength basic sites appeared. In addition, it can be seen from the NH3-TPD profiles (Fig. S9b) that there is a decrease in strong acid sites. Consequently, variations in acidity/basicity and the content of Oα might account for the minor decrease in catalyst activity after usage. Substrate scope As previously mentioned, cyclic carbonates are significant fine chemicals and intermediates used for various applications. For example, glycerol carbonate (GLC) is an important renewable chemical, that produces glycidol (GD), which could further react with amines to form polyurethanes [76]. Therefore, acid-base bifunctional Zr-100 is expected to be used in the synthesis of various cyclic carbonates. To study the universality of the Zr-100 catalyst, different diols like 1,2-diols 1,2-pentanediol, 1,3-butanediol, and 2,3-butanediol were used as substrates to synthesize the corresponding cyclic carbonates, and the results are shown in Table 3 . It is seen that the selectivity is more than 90 % and most of the corresponding cyclic carbonate yields are higher than 90 %. The reduced yield of 1,3-butene carbonate (5 b ) can be attributed to the ring tension present in the six-membered ring, which hinders the formation of the ring [77]. Above all, the Zr-100 catalyst demonstrated significant catalytic activity in cyclic carbonate synthesis by transesterification of DMC with diols. Conclusion The transesterification reaction of diols is a significant method for synthesizing cyclic carbonates. In this work, the synthesis of 1,2-BC via the transesterification of 1,2-BDO with DMC was investigated over tetragonal (t-ZrO2), monoclinic (m-ZrO2), and mixed-phase (mp-ZrO2) zirconia catalysts. Among them, t-ZrO2 exposing the (101) crystal plane and possessing abundant acid-base sites and the highest oxygen vacancy concentration, showed superior intrinsic activity (space-time yield of 41.76 g 1,2-BC gcat. −1 h−1) in the transesterification reaction. In situ DRIFTS results indicated that the surface of t-ZrO2 (101) crystal plane was more favorable for the adsorption and activation of the reactants. The catalytic stability test of t-ZrO2 showed that the production of 1,2-BC remained stable at 95 % for 100 h. Moreover, t-ZrO2 also exhibited excellent catalytic activity for the synthesis of various cyclic carbonates. This study highlighted the significant influence of the surface oxygen vacancies and acid-base properties of ZrO2 on catalyst activity, providing further insights into their relationship with the ZrO2 phase. coredata.dc:description: Cyclic carbonates are valuable green chemicals with wide-ranging applications, but their conventional synthesis often involves toxic reagents or inefficient catalytic systems. In this work, zirconia catalysts with different crystalline phases (tetragonal, monoclinic, and mixed-phase) were developed and evaluated for the transesterification of 1,2-butanediol with dimethyl carbonate. The tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2) exhibited superior catalytic activity (space-time yield of 41.76 g1,2-BC gcat. −1 h−1) due to favorable surface properties and exposed active (101) facet. This study establishes a green, efficient route for 1,2-butylene carbonate synthesis, providing key insights into catalyst structure-activity relationships.
